content.title: Primary Gas Exchange
content.description: The lungs' main function is to exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide through millions of tiny air sacs called alveoli.

content.title: Total Lung Capacity
content.description: An average adult's total lung capacity is about 6 liters, though only a portion is used during normal breathing.

content.title: Millions of Alveoli
content.description: The lungs contain roughly 480 million alveoli, giving them a massive surface area for efficient oxygen absorption.

content.title: Role of the Diaphragm
content.description: Breathing is powered by the diaphragm, a dome-shaped muscle that contracts to draw air into the lungs.

content.title: Right vs. Left Lung
content.description: The right lung has three lobes while the left lung has two lobes, making room for the heart.

content.title: Branching Airways
content.description: Air travels through branching tubes called bronchi and bronchioles before reaching the alveoli.

content.title: Self-Cleaning System
content.description: The lungs use mucus and tiny hair-like cilia to trap and remove dust, microbes, and other particles from the airways.

content.title: Adjusting to Oxygen Needs
content.description: The lungs automatically increase breathing rate during exercise to supply more oxygen and remove excess carbon dioxide.
